page.title: 06B'NESS/SOLWAY. LANDSCAPE.
page.content: To the North Bowness faces & edges the Solway. West, East & South, the whole estuary was once scoured by a fading glacial stream. The result is mainly flat plainland, formed by Ice-Age deposit sand, silts and gravels. Some silted hollows became peat mosses.Some boulder house-corner protectors in the village were once glacial "erratics". Sand & silt have contributed to good modern farmland, together with reclaimed peat moss. Bowness Flow was drained,1845, & capable of good arable cropping after 2 years. Strong winds contribute to use of a small, stable field pattern, with characteristic high, well-treed shelter hedgerows. Extensive marshland either side of village is composed of fine, sandy loam cut by deep drainage creeks and is grazed in season.
